On Escalation Ticket # 00426665 the new comment has been added: Cristiana-Ioana Jeler:

Hello, @WaitingOnEngineer

This issue is reproducing on my side, but only in clipboard. When I try to copy the word "șeker", it won't be blocked. However, on a classic file upload test to dlptest.endpointprotector.com, the word is detected correctly. 

Could you please confirm that the problem is related to the clipboard also on the customer side? Please do some tests both with file uploads and with clipboard. 

If the case is as mentioned above, then we already have an issue created which is targeted for v5.9.5.0 (#345111).

Thank you!
FYI @Cristian-Alexandru Halmajan @Krzysztof Staszalek

On Escalation Ticket # 00426665 the new comment has been added: Hello @Cristina,

Customer returned with the following statement:

Previously, I only performed tests using TXT files. Additionally, I tested the same content using PDF, Word, and Excel files.

In TXT files, blocking only occurs when all letters are written in uppercase. However, in PDF, Word, and Excel files, it detected and blocked everything.

I’m also sharing the sample files, screenshot and the screen recording.

On Escalation Ticket # 00426665 the new comment has been added: Cristiana-Ioana Jeler:

Hello @WaitingOnEngineer, 

The issue is also reproducing on my side as described in the latest comment: in text files, content is blocked only when all letters are capitals and in all other filetypes, content is blocked as expected. 

I assume this has something to do with the way text with special characters is extracted from the text files. This is still under investigation in order to find the exact cause and a possible solution for it. 

Thank you!

[DevOps CommentId:11684898]

On Escalation Ticket # 00426665 the Following Fields have been updated: 
Status has been changed to Awaiting R&D.

On Escalation Ticket # 00426665 the Following Fields have been updated: 
Status has been changed to Awaiting Escalating Engineer.

On Escalation Ticket # 00426665 the new comment has been added: Cristiana-Ioana Jeler:

Hello @WaitingOnEngineer,

After doing some more investigations and tests, the reason why this is happening is because for those specific files where we don't block the word, we detect a different character encoding than in the other cases.

The character encoding detection uses a probabilistic method. So for text files specifically, other character encoding might be sometimes determined if the text is too short (as in this case where there is only one word in those files).

Generally, this should not happen when there is a larger text in the file. Please try to redo the tests, by adding more text in the text files, not solely the word that should be blocked. In such situation, the files should be blocked as expected, as the character encoding would be correctly determined.

Thank you!
